title: Heartbreaking Last Photo Of Boy, 3, Youngest Victim Killed In South Korea Plane Crash - News18
summary:
Heartbreaking Last Photo Of Boy, 3, Youngest Victim Killed In South Korea Plane Crash

Date: December 31, 2024 Source: News18

A devastating final photo emerged of the three-year-old boy who was killed in the South Korean plane crash alongside his parents. Kang Ko, his wife Jin Lee Seon, and their son were tragically lost in the Jeju Air Boeing 737-800 crash while attempting an emergency landing at Muan International Airport.

  • The plane crash claimed 179 lives on December 31, 2024.
  • The boy was on his first trip abroad for Christmas.
  • Kang Ko worked in public relations for the Kia Tigers baseball team.
  • Two flight attendants were the only survivors among the 181 people onboard.
  • Authorities are investigating the crash.
“He was so good at his job that everyone on our company’s baseball broadcasting team liked him.” - Jung Woo-young

This tragic event highlights the fragility of life and the deep impact such incidents have on families and communities.
newTitle: Heartbreaking Last Photo Of Boy, 3, Youngest Victim Killed In South Korea Plane Crash

title: Baby John box office collection day 7: Varun Dhawan film ends first week with barely any growth, mints over ₹32 crore - Hindustan Times
summary:
Baby John box office collection day 7: Varun Dhawan film ends first week with barely any growth, mints over ₹32 crore

Date: Dec 31, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

The Varun Dhawan-starrer 'Baby John' was released on December 25 but has seen a steady decline in box office collections over its first week, managing to mint just over ₹32 crore.

  • The film opened strongly with ₹11.25 crore on its first day.
  • However, a significant drop was observed on the second day with earnings of ₹4.75 crore, marking a 57.78% decline.
  • By the seventh day, the film collected approximately ₹1.81 crore.
  • Overall occupancy in Hindi was reported at 10.68% on December 31.
“Overall, there’s nothing much that makes Baby John stand out apart from the action.”

The film, directed by Kalees and features other actors like Keerthy Suresh and Jackie Shroff, tells the story of a police officer who must confront his past to protect his daughter. Despite its mixed reviews, the film has struggled to perform well at the box office.
newTitle: Baby John Box Office Collection on Day 7 Shows Decline

title: 5 warning signs of Vitamin B12 deficiency in your feet you shouldn't ignore - The Times of India
summary:
5 Warning Signs of Vitamin B12 Deficiency in Your Feet

Publication Date: [Date not provided] Source: Times of India

The symptoms of Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to nerve damage and affect daily life. It's essential to recognize early signs to prevent irreversible damage.

  • Numbness and tingling in feet
  • Burning sensation in extremities
  • Difficulty walking or loss of balance
  • Pale or yellowish skin on feet
  • Persistent cold feet
“According to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), peripheral neuropathy caused by B12 deficiency can become irreversible if untreated.”

Recognizing these signs early can help in addressing Vitamin B12 deficiency and maintaining overall nerve health.
newTitle: 5 Warning Signs of Vitamin B12 Deficiency in Your Feet

West Bengal defeated Kerala 1-0 in the final match of the Santosh Trophy 2024-25 played at the Gachibowli Stadium in Hyderabad, clinching their 33rd title in a dramatic finish.

  • Robi scored the match-winning goal during stoppage time, sealing the victory for West Bengal.

"Robi scores!! Manotos Maji heads the ball into the box for Robi Hansda who has the easiest of finishes from point-blank range."

The victory reaffirms West Bengal's status as a powerhouse in Indian football, continuing their legacy in the prestigious Santosh Trophy.

title: No talk with me, India won’t back any regime change move in Maldives, says former President Nasheed - The Indian Express
summary:
Nasheed Responds to Claims of Indian Involvement in Maldives Regime Change

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: The Indian Express

Former President of Maldives, Mohamed Nasheed, addressed reports of a supposed plot involving Indian intelligence and the Maldivian Opposition to oust current President Mohamed Muizzu. He clarified that India would not support such efforts.

  • Nasheed refutes claims that he was involved in talks for regime change supported by India.
  • Reports suggest a plan to bribe MPs and military officials to impeach President Muizzu.
  • Indian government sources denied any involvement, labeling the report a “figment of imagination”.
“I do not believe that India will be willing to assist the Maldives Opposition in regime change and they certainly have never had any such conversation with me,” Nasheed stated.

Nasheed emphasizes India's respect for Maldivian democracy and highlights the importance of strengthening democratic processes in the Maldives.

title: "No One Can Stop...": China's Xi Jinping Ends 2024 With A Threat To Taiwan - NDTV
summary:
Xi Jinping Issues Strong Warning to Taiwan as 2024 Approaches

Publication Date: New Year’s Eve

Source: New Delhi

Chinese President Xi Jinping ended the year with a firm statement regarding Taiwan, asserting that "no one can stop the reunification" with China. His address highlights the ongoing tensions between Beijing and Taipei amidst military escalations.

  • President Xi emphasized the notion of blood ties between Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
  • Recent military drills have been conducted by China, aimed at applying pressure on Taiwan, especially post-elections.
  • The US views Taiwan as a key strategic ally, complicating the relationship between Beijing and Washington.
  • Xijinping's threats are particularly significant as they come just before Donald Trump’s inauguration as US President.
“Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are one family. No one can sever our blood ties.” - Xi Jinping

In conclusion, Xi's declarations signal a potential escalation in tensions in the coming year, as China remains steadfast in its claims over Taiwan.
newTitle: Xi Jinping Issues Strong Warning to Taiwan as 2024 Approaches

title: Delhi LG's office replies to Atishi's letter on religious structures: ‘CM playing cheap politics’ - Hindustan Times
summary:
Delhi LG's Office Responds to Atishi Over Allegations of Religious Structure Demolitions

Date: December 31, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

The ongoing conflict between Delhi's Lieutenant Governor Vinai Kumar Saxena and Chief Minister Atishi escalates as Atishi accuses the LG of planning to demolish multiple religious structures. The LG's office denies these claims, asserting that the CM is engaging in political theatrics.

  • Atishi alleged that a religious committee headed by the LG decided to demolish various religious structures, which would hurt the sentiments of communities.
  • The LG's office refuted the claims, stating no demolition orders have been issued.
  • LG emphasized the need for vigilance against vandalism and criticized the CM for attempting to shift focus from governance issues.
  • The exchange included remarks about Atishi being labeled a 'temporary Chief Minister' by the LG, which prompted further debate on the nature of political roles.
“Demolition of these structures would hurt the religious sentiments of these communities.” - Atishi
“CM is playing cheap politics to divert attention from her and her predecessor CM's failures.” - Delhi LG's office

The contentious back-and-forth highlights ongoing tensions in Delhi's political landscape, as allegations and responses focus on governance and accountability.
newTitle: Delhi LG's Office Responds to Atishi Over Allegations of Religious Structure Demolitions

title: Jupiter’s Great Red Spot isn’t as permanent as we thought | Mint - Mint
summary:
Jupiter’s Great Red Spot isn’t as permanent as we thought

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Mint

Jupiter’s Great Red Spot, a massive storm capable of engulfing Earth, is not as stable as previously believed. Recent research indicates that the storm's size continues to change over time.

  • The Great Red Spot is observed to be larger than the one first documented by Giovanni Cassini in 1665.
  • New findings challenge the notion of its permanence, suggesting dynamic changes occur.
  • Continued observation of this atmospheric phenomenon is critical for understanding planetary storms.
newTitle: Jupiter’s Great Red Spot: A Changing Storm

title: OpenAI Whistleblower Suchir Balaji’s Mother Speaks Out: ‘Elon Musk Believes It’s A Murder’ - News18
summary:
Suchir Balaji's Mother Claims Elon Musk Believes Her Son's Death Is A Murder

Date: December 31, 2024

Source: CNN-News18

Suchir Balaji's mother, Poornima Rao, expressed her concerns about the investigation into her son's death, alleging neglect by authorities and raising suspicions of foul play.

  • Suchir Balaji, a 26-year-old researcher at OpenAI, was found dead in his apartment earlier this month.
  • Authorities ruled the death a suicide, but the family contests this, having hired a private investigator.
  • Poornima Rao claims signs of disturbance in the apartment contradict the suicide ruling.
  • Elon Musk publicly stated he believes the circumstances do not suggest suicide.
  • No suicide note was found, and CCTV footage from the scene has not been shared with the family.
“This doesn’t seem like a suicide.” - Elon Musk

The case has drawn attention, calling for further investigation as the family seeks clarity and justice regarding Suchir's death.
newTitle: Suchir Balaji's Mother Claims Elon Musk Believes Her Son's Death Is A Murder

title: Security forces clash with Kuki women in Manipur’s Kangpokpi - The Hindu
summary:
Clashes Erupt Between Security Forces and Kuki Women in Manipur

Date: December 31, 2024 Source: The Hindu

A violent clash occurred between a mob of Kuki-Zo women and security forces in Manipur's Kangpokpi district, escalating ethnic tensions in the region.

  • The incident took place at Uyokching while the security forces were being deployed.
  • Police reported that the forces used minimal force to disperse the crowd.
  • Locals claimed injuries resulted from the security personnel's actions.
  • A Kuki leader alleged escalation due to the use of tear gas by the forces.
  • The Committee on Tribal Unity blocked a critical national highway in response, demanding the withdrawal of forces.
“Our people have suffered enough. The use of excessive force on unarmed women is unacceptable,” — CoTU spokesperson.

This incident highlights ongoing ethnic strife in Manipur, particularly affecting the Kuki community during a significant holiday period.
newTitle: Clashes Erupt Between Security Forces and Kuki Women in Manipur

title: Explainer: What happens when Russian gas supply to Europe via Ukraine ends? - Reuters
summary:
Explainer: What Happens When Russian Gas Supply to Europe via Ukraine Ends?

Date: Dec 31, 2023 Source: Reuters

Russian gas supplies through Ukraine, which have been in place for over 40 years, are set to end on January 1, 2024, following Ukraine's refusal to renew a transit deal with Gazprom. This marks a significant shift in Europe's energy landscape amid ongoing geopolitical tensions.

  • Ukraine's Naftogaz will not renew its five-year transit deal with Gazprom, halting supplies that amount to millions of cubic meters.
  • Since the onset of the Ukraine conflict, the EU’s dependency on Russian gas has dramatically declined, with market share dropping from 35% to about 8%.
  • The European Commission believes that current demands can be met through alternative sources like LNG and non-Russian pipeline imports.
  • Countries such as Austria and Slovakia will feel the impact, with Austria heavily reliant on gas from Ukraine.
  • Slovakia has secured alternative supply contracts with companies like BP and Eni to mitigate the effects of the loss.
“Gazprom plans to suspend supply to Moldova on Jan. 1 citing unpaid bills.”

In conclusion, the cessation of Russian gas transit via Ukraine not only affects immediate energy supplies but also highlights a crucial turning point for European energy security.
newTitle: Explainer: What Happens When Russian Gas Supply to Europe via Ukraine Ends?

title: Kerala nurse sentenced to death in Yemen: All you need to know about the case and Indian govt’s response - OpIndia
summary:
Kerala Nurse Sentenced to Death in Yemen: All You Need to Know About the Case and Indian Govt’s Response

Publication Date: December 31, 2024 Source: India Today

Indian nurse Nimisha Priya has been sentenced to death in Yemen after being convicted of murder in a 2017 case. The Indian government is exploring options to help her appeal against the sentence.

Nimisha Priya’s Arrest and Case Background

Nimisha Priya was arrested in July 2017 for the murder of Yemeni citizen Talal Abdo Mahdi, with sentencing taking place three years later.

  • The death sentence could potentially be overturned if Mahdi's family agrees to accept blood money.
  • Efforts are underway by her family to negotiate with the victim's family for pardon.
  • The Indian Ministry of External Affairs has stated they are providing all possible support in this matter.

Key Developments in the Case

In a tragic series of disputes, Priya injected Mahdi with sedatives, leading to his death from overdose.

  • Priya had been facing threats and harassment from Mahdi over a failed business partnership.
  • Concerns regarding payment to the lawyer appointed for her defense led to stalled negotiations for blood money.
  • The appeals process in the Yemeni Supreme Court has already been rejected as of November 2023.
“We are aware of the sentencing of Nimisha Priya in Yemen. The government is extending all possible help in the matter.” - MEA spokesperson Randhir Jaiswal

The case highlights serious concerns regarding legal coercion, rights of foreign nationals in Yemen, and the complexities surrounding international legal assistance.
newTitle: Death Sentence for Indian Nurse in Yemen: Understanding the Case and Government Response

title: Small savings schemes: Interest rates on PPF, SSY, SCSS remain unchanged for January-March quarter; Check rates | Mint - Mint
summary:
Small savings schemes: Interest rates on PPF, SSY, SCSS remain unchanged for January-March quarter; Check rates

Date: December 31, 2024

Source: Live Mint

The central government has announced that the interest rates for various small savings schemes will remain unchanged for the January to March quarter of FY 2024-25, marking the fourth consecutive quarter with no adjustments.

  • The interest rates for Public Provident Fund (PPF) and National Savings Certificate (NSC) are kept at 7.1 per cent and 7.7 per cent, respectively.
  • Kisan Vikas Patra (KVP) interest rate is set at 7.5 per cent.
  • The Senior Citizen Savings Scheme (SCSS) will continue at 8.2 per cent.
  • The Sukanya Samriddhi Yojana (SSY) maintains an interest rate of 8.2 per cent.
  • Post Office Monthly Income Scheme (PO-MIS) offers an interest rate of 7.4 per cent.
  • Deposits made in the five-year recurring deposit (RD) scheme will earn 6.7 per cent.
The government notifies the interest rates on small savings schemes every quarter, based on recommendations from the Shyamala Gopinath Committee.

This stability in interest rates comes as a strategy to promote consistent savings behavior across various demographics, especially among senior citizens and parents saving for their daughters' future.
newTitle: Small Saving Schemes Maintain Interest Rates for January-March Quarter
